item.description:
Self-control, self regulation, discipline, delayed gratification...willpower

 

Temptation

 

Did you keep your New Year's resolution?  Did you say "No" to that donut this morning?

 

Walter Mischel, and his fellow researchers sought to better understand the ability to delay immediate gratification in a test using 4 year olds and marshmallows.  Each child was brought into a room, where on the table was a single marshmallow.  The researcher told the child they could eat the marshmallow.

However, if they were willing to wait 15 minutes until the researcher returned, they could have 2 marshmallows.

 

How many of the kids were able to wait?   In what ways, what methods, did those who waited manage to do so?   

 

Decades later, researchers followed up on how these children did as adults. What did they discover?

What are the limits of willpower?  What are the benefits in being able to resist temptation?

 How can we improve our willpower muscle?

 

Let's have a discussion on will power, how it works and how to build it up. For the latest research and lessons, we'll explore the new book...  Willpower: Rediscovering the Greatest Human Strength, by Roy F. Baumeister

 

Meetup date subject to change.
item.name: The Marshmallow Test
